title: 112_hr1455
content: The Act may be cited as the "9/11 First Responders History Project Act of 2011". Congress finds that over 410,000 people, including 91,000 rescue and recovery workers, were exposed to the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks at the World Trade Center. PTSD was a major health effect for responders, with 19% of adult enrollees reporting new symptoms, four times the typical rate in the US. 11% of rescue and recovery workers monitored over a five-year period met criteria for PTSD. According to a study, over a five-year period from 2002 to 2007, 11% of rescue and recovery workers exposed to the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks at the World Trade Center met criteria for probable PTSD. The rate of PTSD among these responders is significantly higher than in the general population and comparable to veterans of the war in Afghanistan. Firefighters who worked at Ground Zero lost an average of 12 years of lung function. The purpose of this Act is to create a federally sponsored project to collect personal histories and testimonials of emergency responders. The Act aims to collect personal histories and testimonials of emergency responders and cleanup workers from the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks to preserve their memories for future generations. Establishment of project at Library of Congress to collect video and audio recordings of histories of 9/11 first responders. The Librarian of Congress will establish an oral history project to survey and collect audio and video recordings, as well as written materials, related to the personal histories of 9/11 first responders. The Librarian of Congress will establish an oral history project to collect recordings and materials related to personal histories, create a catalog, and make the collection available to the public. This may involve partnerships with other entities and consultation with experts and volunteers. The Librarian of Congress may procure services, accept volunteers, and make advance payments for activities under the Act. They will begin collecting recordings and materials, prioritizing the oldest individuals involved. The Librarian of Congress will collect recordings and materials from 9/11 first responders, prioritizing the oldest individuals involved. SEC. 4 encourages donations to support activities under section 3, with funds dedicated solely to the Library of Congress. SEC. 5 authorizes appropriations. SEC. 5 authorizes appropriations of $250,000 for fiscal year 2012 and $150,000 for each of the 4 succeeding fiscal years.
